title-group.article-title: Book Review: The Developing Human Brain: Growth and Adversities

contrib.aff: Creighton University School of Medicine, Omaha, Nebraska.

article-meta.product: Gilles FH Nelson MDJr. The Developing Human Brain: Growth and Adversities. Clinics in Developmental Medicine No. 193. London, UK: Mac Keith Press, 2012. pp. $170.50. ISBN 978-1-908316-41-7.

body.p:
The Collaborative Perinatal Project (CPP) of the National Institute of Neurological and Communicative Disorders and Stroke (NINCDS), in which approximately 42 000 pregnant women were enrolled and 55 000 children born, was a prospective study devoted to the understanding of childhood neurologic disorders and other conditions. PSG Publishing Inc (later John Wright PSG Inc), which is the same publisher that originated the Journal of Child Neurology,1 produced a series of books concerning the Collaborative Perinatal Project data.2
–6 One of those books, prepared in 1983 by Gilles, Leviton, and Dooling, concerned the developing human brain.5 Now 29 years later, Floyd Gilles (a pediatric neuropathologist) has teamed with Marvin Nelson Jr (a pediatric neuroradiologist) to produce a follow-up volume that emphasizes the relationship of developmental changes in the brain to imaging features. The first section (7 chapters) in the book elucidates normal prenatal brain growth, whereas the second section (9 chapters) describes a variety of abnormalities, including vascular disorders and intracranial hemorrhage. There are many excellent tables, diagrams, and figures demonstrating the material described throughout the book. This is a valuable text concerning fetal brain changes and will be an especially important reference for those child neurologists involved in the practice of neonatal neurology.
